column1: Effects on physical activity, physical fitness and well-being in a 36-months randomized controlled study, comparing a multimodal hospital-based intervention programme for primary cardiovascular prevention with usual care

column12:
- Specific scale used: World Health Organization Well-Being Index (WHO-5)
- Specific constructs measured: Psychological well-being, including feelings of cheerfulness, calmness, activity, freshness, and interest in daily life
- Measurement time points: Baseline and follow-up
- Scoring method: Each item scored from 0 to 5, then translated into a percentage scale from 0 to 100

column13:
- Duration of follow-up periods: 3 years
- Changes in outcomes at different follow-up time points:
  - Physical activity levels increased significantly in the intervention group compared to the control group (mean difference in PAI scores: 1.07, 95% CI: 0.21 to 1.93, p = 0.015).
  - No significant changes in cardiorespiratory fitness in either group.
  - Psychological well-being improved in both groups, but the increase was larger in the intervention group (mean difference: 5.06, 95% CI: 0.68 to 9.45, p = 0.024; not significant when controlling for baseline imbalance).
  - Use of antihypertensive medication increased more significantly in the control group (p = 0.044).
- Evidence of sustained effects or relapse:
  - Physical activity levels were sustained over the 3-year follow-up period in the intervention group.
  - No sustained effects on cardiorespiratory fitness.
  - Psychological well-being improvements were sustained but not statistically significant when controlling for baseline imbalance.
column14:
- "On this background we conducted the Hjerteløftet Study, a randomized controlled trial to examine effects of a multimodal intervention programme including a hospital-based lifestyle course and primary care followup over 36 months, in individuals with elevated cardiovascular risk"
  - "The present study population hence represents a random sample from both arms of the original total of 701 patients who participated in the Hjerteløftet Study in the period 2011-2019"
  - "A random sample from the original Hjerteløftet Study was included for further examinations ( n = 255, 40% women), and these patients were already randomized to an intervention group (IG) ( n = 127), or a control group (CG) ( n = 128)."
  - "A permuted block randomization was generated, and sealed opaque envelopes with consecutive inclusion numbers were made."
  - "The trial was funded in a grant from the Norwegian Ministry of Health and Care Services and The Patient National Organization for Heart and Lung Diseases."
column16:

- The use of "permuted block randomization" and "sealed opaque envelopes" further supports the randomized controlled trial design, as these are methods used to ensure randomization.
- The study involves an intervention group and a control group, which is characteristic of a randomized controlled trial.
- The study is also longitudinal, as it follows participants over a period of 36 months to assess changes in physical activity, fitness, and well-being.
- The study is observational in nature as well, as it observes the effects of the intervention over time without manipulating variables beyond the intervention itself.

column20:
- "The Hjerteløftet intervention programme is previously described [2] and is only briefly summarized here. Patients randomized to the intervention group (IG) participated in a 5-day hospital-based lifestyle course in a specialized cardiac rehabilitation hospital (CR Hospital) which focused on PA, nutrition, smoking cessation, stress-management, motivation and individual goal-setting."
  - "More specific regarding the exercise intervention, the aim during the course was to educate the patients about the benefits of exercise and the safety of exertion despite the presence of cardiovascular risk factors."
  - "Exercise sessions consisted of aerobic exercises, interval training, resistance training, aqua-aerobics and attention training."
  - "The purpose of the exercise-programme was to introduce the individuals to a wide spectrum of activities and sports to make it more likely they would find activities of interest which they would be able to continue in the future."
  - "During the course the patients made a graded exercise plan for the follow-up period themselves, supported by the study staff, tailored to the patient`s lifestyle, motivation and PA level."
  - "The 3-year follow-up period was allocated to primary care and included a periodic digital follow-up option from the hospital."
  - "Regarding exercise, both the type of activity, the frequency, intensity and the duration of the activity sessions during the follow-up period were decisions made by the patient."

column26:
- "The patients` experiences related to psychological wellbeing were assessed using the five-item World Health Organization Well-Being Index (WHO-5), which is among the most widely used questionnaires assessing subjective psychological well-being"
  - "The short questionnaire is reported to have adequate validity as an outcome measure in clinical trials."
  - "The questionnaire contains the following items (1) "I have felt cheerful and in good spirits", (2) "I have felt calm and relaxed", (3) "I have felt active and vigorous", (4) "I woke up feeling fresh and rested" and ( 5) "My daily life has been filled with things that interest me"."
  - "The patient is asked to rate how well each of the statements applies to her or him when considering the last 14 days."
  - "Each of the 5 items is scored from 0 (none of the time) to 5 (all the time) and a raw score therefore ranges from 0 (absence of well-being) to 25 (maximal well-being)."
  - "The raw score is multiplied with 4, translating the scale into a percentage scale from 0 (absent) to 100 (maximal)."
  - "The WHO-5 score increased in both groups during follow-up"
  - "The difference between mean change scores indicated a significant increase of 5.06, 95% CI: 0.68 to 9.45, p = 0.024, on intervention vs. control."
  - "When controlling for baseline imbalance using ANCOVA, the difference between the mean change scores of each treatment group was 3.28 and no longer significant (95%CI: 0.68 to 9.45, p = 0.104)."
column28:
- The paper uses the World Health Organization Well-Being Index (WHO-5) to measure psychological well-being.
- The WHO-5 is a five-item questionnaire that assesses subjective psychological well-being by asking about feelings of cheerfulness, calmness, activity, freshness, and interest in daily life.
- Each item is scored from 0 to 5, and the raw score is then translated into a percentage scale from 0 to 100.
- The WHO-5 was administered at baseline and follow-up to assess changes in psychological well-being.
- The results showed a significant increase in WHO-5 scores in both groups, with a larger increase in the intervention group compared to the control group.
- The significant increase was reported with a mean difference of 5.06, but this became non-significant when controlling for baseline imbalance.
column29:
- "The 3-year follow-up period was allocated to primary care and included a periodic digital follow-up option from the hospital."
  - "Follow-up was based on each patient`s individual plan for achieving and maintaining risk factor control decided at the lifestyle course."
  - "The CG received care as usual in the community health care by the GP."
  - "A total of 255 individuals (40% women) were included in this substudy, out of the main study population of 701, whereof 127 patients from the IG and 128 from the CG."
  - "After randomization, 7 patients in the IG and 20 patients in the CG were lost to follow up."
  - "Finally, 228 (89.5%) patients remained in the follow-up study population, with 120 (95%) patients in the IG and 108 (84%) in the CG"
  - "PA levels increased significantly more in the IG compared to the CG during follow-up."
  - "The difference between the mean change PAI scores was 1.07, 95% CI: 0.21 to 1.93, p = 0.015 on intervention vs usual care."
  - "The difference remained significant when controlling for baseline imbalance using ANCOVA; 0.90, 95% CI: 0.10 to 1.70, p = 0.028,"
  - "There were no corresponding differences in cardiorespiratory fitness."
  - "The WHO-5 score increased in both groups during follow-up"
  - "The difference between mean change scores indicated a significant increase of 5.06, 95% CI: 0.68 to 9.45, p = 0.024, on intervention vs. control."
  - "When controlling for baseline imbalance using ANCOVA, the difference between the mean change scores of each treatment group was 3.28 and no longer significant (95%CI: 0.68 to 9.45, p = 0.104)."
  - "Only minor, nonsignificant changes were observed for traditional risk factors and cardiometabolic variables."
  - "The use of antihypertensive medication increased significantly more in the CG ( p = 0.044)."
  - "A major finding in the present substudy of a primary prevention trial [2], was a statistically significant increased PA level in favour of the IG."
  - "The program also resulted in a within group significant decrease in the proportion of patients reporting being inactive in the IG, while the decrease was less prominent in the CG."
  - "In contrast, the records showed that there were no changes in CRF in either group during 3 years of follow-up, and no differences between groups."
  - "The true potential of lifestyle intervention regarding cardiovascular risk reducing effects cannot be expected to be realized in a study like the current one, as the intervention was not tightly controlled, the inclusion did not require any high commitment of the patients, and follow-up was to a large degree left to the patient and the primary care health system, already being short on resources."
  - "A more intense and shorter intervention period would most likely result in larger effects of the parameters explored in the present substudy, but the generalization of the findings to public health efforts would then be more questionable."
  - "Our study also has some limitations. Due to the nature of the intervention, neither the study staff nor the patients were blinded for the treatment. This may have contributed to both performance and detection bias as knowledge about treatment allocation might have influenced both health care providers and the patients` behaviour."
  - "The CG also performed a one-day assessment at baseline and at follow-up in the CR Hospital, including the CPET. The follow-up and the study focus on PA, fitness and lifestyle may have motivated patients in the CG and thereby reduced the between-group difference in exercise and other favourable lifestyle changes."
  - "A limitation of the study is also the risk of attrition bias. The overall loss to follow-up was 10.6%, which may be expected in a lifestyle study with a follow-up time as long as 3 years."
  - "The difference in drop-out rates between groups, however, with more dropouts in the CG (20/128, 15.6%) than in the IG (7/127, 5.5%), may relate to that the patients wanted to participate in the study because of motivation for lifestyle change and consequently may have been disappointed when allocated to usual care."
  - "Another limitation of the study was the large number of invalid accelerometer-registrations. The findings regarding PA must be considered with some caution, as analyses on changes between baseline and follow-up are based on self-reports only, and confirmation through objective measurements were hampered."
  - "It should also be noted that we have limited knowledge of the adherence and the time course of the intervention effects in this study, as no interim evaluations were carried out between baseline and 3 years of follow-up."
  - "Although in-between measurements could have added interesting knowledge regarding patients` behaviour, this was not prioritized. As the main aim of the study was to assess the effects of the intervention programme on total cardiovascular risk after 3 years, interim assessments were not considered pivotal, and omitted because of resource considerations."
column31:
- The study had a follow-up period of 3 years, which is a significant duration for assessing sustainability.
- Physical activity levels increased significantly in the intervention group compared to the control group during follow-up, with a mean difference in PAI scores of 1.07 (95% CI: 0.21 to 1.93, p = 0.015).
- There were no significant changes in cardiorespiratory fitness in either group during the follow-up period.
- Psychological well-being improved in both groups, but the increase was larger in the intervention group, although not statistically significant when controlling for baseline imbalance.
- The use of antihypertensive medication increased more significantly in the control group compared to the intervention group.
- The study had limitations, including lack of blinding, potential performance and detection bias, and a risk of attrition bias due to differential dropout rates.
- The intervention was not tightly controlled, and follow-up was largely left to primary care, which may have affected sustainability.
- There were no interim evaluations between baseline and 3-year follow-up, which limits understanding of adherence and time course effects.

- "The intervention was tested in a randomized controlled trial and was comprised of an Internet program—DirectLife (Philips)—aimed at increasing physical activity using monitoring and feedback by accelerometry and feedback by digital coaching (n=119)."
  - "The DirectLife program comprised components that are based on the stages of change and the I-Change model. Briefly, this model assumes that behavioral change is the result of individual awareness of one's behavior, motivation to change behavior and action, and taking into account the individual's current activity level; it subsequently provides a personal goal"
  - "DirectLife consists of three elements: (1) an accelerometer-based activity monitor, (2) a personal website, and (3) a personal e-coach, who provides regular updates of the individual's physical activity status by email and gives advice on how to increase physical activity."
  - "Participants of the program were instructed to wear the activity monitor continuously throughout the day to measure daily physical activity."
  - "After an initial 8-day assessment period starting 1 week after the study visit, in which the current level of daily activity was measured, a target was set to increase the level of daily activity during a 12-week Internet-based interactive coaching program."
  - "Personalized targets were set by the DirectLife program and were defined as the absolute increase in physical activity compared to the individual's baseline assessment data."
  - "Participants were given a target for daily activity, which increased weekly, and data from the accelerometer were used for regular feedback."
  - "Coaching included general recommendations on physical activities and coaches were available for further questions and advice by email correspondence."
  - "The control group was placed on a 3-month waiting list after which they received access to the intervention program at the end of the study."
  - "Enrollment and follow-up took place from November 2011 to August 2012."

column26:
- "Health-related quality of life was assessed at baseline and at 3-month follow-up, with the use of the self-administered standard Dutch paper version of the Research ANd Development (RAND) 36-item health survey (RAND-36)"
  - "The RAND-36 questionnaire entails eight domains of health-related quality of life pertaining to both physical and mental health."
  - "The domains of physical functioning (10 items), limitations on usual role-related activities due to physical health problems (four items), pain (two items), and general health perception (five items) comprise the physical component; the domains of vitality (four items), social functioning (two items), limitations on usual role-related activities due to emotional or mental problems (three items), and emotional or mental problems (three items) comprise the mental component."
  - "Scores on the subscales range from 0 to 100, with higher scores indicating better health or functioning."
  - "The total RAND-36 score is the sum of the scores on the subscales and ranges from 0 to 800, where 0 is the poorest quality of life and 800 the best imaginable."
  - "A total of 50 of the 119 participants (42.0%) in the intervention group successfully reached their physical activity target and showed a significant improvement in quality of life compared to the control group for subscales on emotional and mental health (4.31 vs -0.72, respectively; P=.009) and health change (11.06 vs 2.03, respectively; P=.004)."
  - "The dose-response analysis showed that there was a significant association between increase in minutes spent in moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) and increase in quality of life."

column1: Effects of need-supportive physical activity counseling on well-being: a 2-year follow-up among sedentary older adults.

column5: Journal of Physical Activity and Health
column9:
- Total sample size: 442
- Age range or mean age: Mean age = 69.48 years, SD = 6.71 years; Age range = 60 to 93 years
- Gender distribution: 66.7% female
- Initial physical activity status: Sedentary

column10:
- REFER: Type - Various physical activities (yoga, dancing, swimming, tennis, cycling); Frequency - Not specified; Duration - Not specified; Total intervention period - Not specified; Setting - Unsupervised.
- WALK: Type - Walking; Frequency - Most days of the week; Duration - Not specified; Total intervention period - Not specified; Setting - Unsupervised.
- COACH: Type - Not specified; Frequency - Every ten days; Duration - Not specified; Total intervention period - 10 weeks; Setting - Supervised (face-to-face contacts or booster phone calls).
column11:
- Motivation strategy: Positive motivation strategy for COACH, as it uses SDT to foster autonomy, competence, and relatedness. REFER and WALK do not specify a motivation strategy.
- Theoretical framework used: Self-Determination Theory (SDT) for COACH.
- Type of intervention support: Counseling for COACH, referral for REFER, structured program for WALK.
column12:
- Specific scales used: Louvain Well-Being Scale, Dutch version of the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory
- Specific constructs measured: Subjective well-being (physical and psychological), trait anxiety
- Measurement time points: Baseline, 10 weeks, 1 year, 2 years
- Significant changes: Improvements in well-being and trait anxiety from baseline to 10 weeks and 1 year; relapse in well-being and increase in trait anxiety by 2 years
column13:
- Duration of follow-up periods: 10 weeks, 1 year, 2 years

  - 10-week follow-up: Significant improvements in well-being and trait anxiety
  - 1-year follow-up: Continued improvements in well-being and trait anxiety
  - 2-year follow-up: Well-being returned to baseline levels; trait anxiety increased significantly

column14:
- "The use of a longitudinal study design constitutes a first strength."
  - "Sedentary older adults (n = 442) were randomized to 3 programs: (1) a one-contact referral to locally organized physical activities, (2) a one-contact provision of a walking program, (3) a 10-week multiple-contact physical activity coaching based on the Self-Determination Theory."
  - "the assessment of well-being and trait anxiety one year and two years after the intervention provided information on the sustainability of the effects of the different PA programs on mental health."
  - "participants were randomly assigned to three PA programs, i.e. (1) a one-contact PA referral, (2) a one-contact walking program, and (3) a ten-week multiple-contact individually-tailored need-supportive PA program."
column16:
- The study involved random assignment of participants to different intervention groups, which is characteristic of a randomized controlled trial (RCT).
- The study followed participants over time, assessing outcomes at multiple follow-up points (10 weeks, 1 year, and 2 years), which indicates a longitudinal study design.
- The combination of randomization and longitudinal follow-up suggests that the study design is both a randomized controlled trial and a longitudinal study.
column17:
- "Sedentary older adults (n = 442) were randomized to 3 programs:"
  - "The final sample consisted of 66.7% female older adults."
  - "The mean age was 69.48 ± 6.71 years, with a maximum of 93 years; Respectively 60.9%, 31.4% and 7.7% of the participants were aged between 60 and 70 years, between 71 and 80 years, and over 80 years."
  - "Older adults who volunteered to participate in the PA program but already attained the PA health norm, 47 were excluded from the study (n = 229)."
  - "Flemish adults aged 60 years or older were invited to an information session on PA health benefits and PA recommendations by a Health Fitness Specialist (MSc) (i.e. participants' PA coach during the intervention)."
  - "The majority of the participants (64.3%) was married or lived together with their partner."
  - "The average number of years of education was 12.09 ± 2.76 years; Respectively 31.0%, 36.4% and 32.6% of the participants had a primary educational level (i.e. at least nine years of education), a secondary educational level (i.e. at least 12 years of education) and a high educational level (i.e. 15 or more years of education)."
  - "Gender, age and years of education were not significantly different between the three conditions."
column19:
- The total sample size is explicitly mentioned as 442 sedentary older adults.
- The mean age is provided as 69.48 years with a standard deviation of 6.71 years, and the age range is detailed as 60 to 93 years.
- The gender distribution is given as 66.7% female.
- The initial physical activity status is described as sedentary.
- The specific population characteristics are older adults, with a focus on Flemish adults aged 60 years or older.
- Additional demographic details include marital status and educational level, but these are not directly related to the physical activity status or age.
column20:
- "Sedentary older adults (n = 442) were randomized to 3 programs: (1) a one-contact referral to locally organized physical activities, (2) a one-contact provision of a walking program, (3) a 10-week multiple-contact physical activity coaching based on the Self-Determination Theory."
  - "REFER consisted of a single 15-minute face-to-face advice session in which the coach explained and referred the older adults to locally-organized PA such as yoga, dancing, swimming, tennis, and cycling."
  - "In addition to the referral and the provision of the self-help booklet, participants of WALK were explained a structured walking program during the single 15-minute face-to-face contact with their coach."
  - "In addition to the referral and the provision the self-help booklet and the walking program, participants of COACH received a ten-week individually-tailored PA coaching based on SDT."
  - "Every ten days, they were supported by their coach through face-to-face contacts or booster phone calls, according to their preferences and needs."
  - "The walking program comprised weekly schedules of uninterrupted walks with progressively increasing volume and intensity on most days of the week."
  - "Participants were encouraged to progress through the different levels of the walking program according to their individual abilities."
column22:
- The study involved three different physical activity intervention groups: REFER, WALK, and COACH.
- REFER: This group involved a single 15-minute face-to-face advice session where participants were referred to local physical activities such as yoga, dancing, swimming, tennis, and cycling. The frequency and duration of these activities are not specified.
- WALK: This group received a structured walking program in addition to the referral. The walking program was designed to increase in volume and intensity over time, with participants encouraged to progress at their own pace. The frequency is implied to be most days of the week, but specific details on duration and total intervention period are not provided.
- COACH: This group received a 10-week individually-tailored coaching based on the Self-Determination Theory. Participants had face-to-face contacts or booster phone calls every ten days. The type of physical activity is not specified, but it was tailored to individual preferences and needs.
column23:
- "SDT-based counseling has repeatedly been shown to be effective in facilitating health-promoting behavior such as PA."
  - "the pursuit and attainment of one's personal goals is expected to produce feelings of need-satisfaction and consequently to enhance subjective health and well-being."
  - "In addition to the referral and the provision of the self-help booklet, participants of WALK were explained a structured walking program during the single 15-minute face-to-face contact with their coach."
  - "In addition to the referral and the provision the self-help booklet and the walking program, participants of COACH received a ten-week individually-tailored PA coaching based on SDT."
  - "During pre-tests, participants were asked for their age, gender and marital status."
  - "The secondary purpose of the study was to examine the extent to which older adults' changes in PA on the one hand and their perceived need-support of the coach on the other hand contribute to the changes in well-being and trait anxiety."
  - "The demonstrated positive effects of need-supportive PA counseling on well-being and trait anxiety in this study are consistent with previous intervention studies that showed psychological benefits due to an autonomy-supportive exercise instructing style among (older) adults."
column25:
- The paper describes three different intervention approaches: REFER, WALK, and COACH. Each has a distinct motivation strategy and type of intervention support.
- REFER involves a one-contact referral to locally organized physical activities, which does not specify a particular motivation strategy but provides a minimal intervention support.
- WALK includes a structured walking program in addition to the referral, which implies a structured program but does not explicitly mention a motivation strategy.
- COACH uses a ten-week multiple-contact individually-tailored PA coaching based on the Self-Determination Theory (SDT), which explicitly fosters autonomy, competence, and relatedness. This suggests a positive motivation strategy as it supports personal goals and need satisfaction.
- The use of SDT in COACH indicates a theoretical framework that supports autonomous motivation, which is a positive motivation strategy.
- The paper highlights the importance of perceived need-support in all interventions, suggesting that this is a key component of the motivation strategy.
column26:
- "Self-reports on well-being, trait anxiety and physical activity were completed at baseline (pretest), and 10 weeks after (10-week follow-up), 1 year after (1-year follow-up) and 2 years after (2-year follow-up) pretests."
  - "Subjective well-being was assessed with the Louvain Well-Being Scale."
  - "Trait anxiety was measured by 11 items of the Dutch version of the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory."
  - "This brief and easy comprehensible questionnaire asks participants to report their frequency of 20-minute bouts of mild, moderate and strenuous PA in a typical week during the previous month."
  - "perceived need-support of the coach was assessed using a modified version of the Teacher As Social Context Questionnaire."
  - "Well-being significantly improved from pre-test to 10-WK FU and from pre-test to 1-YR FU (all P = .000)"
  - "Trait anxiety significantly improved from pre-test to 10-WK FU (P = .004), from 10-WK FU to 1-YR FU (P = .020) and consequently from pre-test to 1-YR FU (P = .000)"
  - "there was a significant decrease from 10-WK FU to 2-YR FU (P = .000) and from 1-YR FU to 2-YR FU (P = .000)."
  - "The abovementioned changes resulted in the absence of a significant change in well-being from pre-test to 2-YR FU (P = .241), indicating a relapse to baseline level two years after the intervention."
  - "The abovementioned changes resulted in a significant increase in trait anxiety from pre-test to 2-YR FU (P = .021)."
column28:
- The paper uses the Louvain Well-Being Scale to measure subjective well-being, which includes both physical and psychological components.
- Trait anxiety is measured using the Dutch version of the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory.
- Physical activity is assessed using a self-report questionnaire, but this is not directly related to life satisfaction or psychological health.
- Perceived need-support is measured using a modified version of the Teacher As Social Context Questionnaire, which is relevant to psychological health.
- Measurements were taken at baseline, 10 weeks, 1 year, and 2 years after the intervention.
- Significant improvements in well-being and trait anxiety were observed from baseline to 10 weeks and 1 year, but there was a relapse in well-being and an increase in trait anxiety by the 2-year follow-up.
column29:
- "Self-reports on well-being, trait anxiety and physical activity were completed at baseline (pretest), and 10 weeks after (10-week follow-up), 1 year after (1-year follow-up) and 2 years after (2-year follow-up) pretests."
  - "All 3 programs yielded improvements in well-being and trait anxiety from pretest to 10-week follow-up and to 1-year follow-up. From pretest to 2-year follow-up, no changes emerged in well-being whereas trait anxiety increased significantly."
  - "Well-being significantly improved from pre-test to 10-WK FU and from pre-test to 1-YR FU (all P = .000)"
  - "Whereas well-being did not change significantly from 10-WK FU to 1-YR FU (P = .769), there was a significant decrease from 10-WK FU to 2-YR FU (P = .000) and from 1-YR FU to 2-YR FU (P = .000)."
  - "The abovementioned changes resulted in the absence of a significant change in well-being from pre-test to 2-YR FU (P = .241), indicating a relapse to baseline level two years after the intervention."
  - "Trait anxiety significantly improved from pre-test to 10-WK FU (P = .004), from 10-WK FU to 1-YR FU (P = .020) and consequently from pre-test to 1-YR FU (P = .000)"
  - "There was a significant increase in trait anxiety from 1-YR FU to 2-YR FU (P = .000) as well as from 10-WK FU to 2-YR FU (P = .000)."
  - "The abovementioned changes resulted in a significant increase in trait anxiety from pre-test to 2-YR FU (P = .021)."
  - "The finding that especially participants with worse initial levels of subjective health improved in well-being and trait anxiety can be explained by the occurrence of a ceiling effect."
  - "However, two years after the intervention, the level of well-being and trait anxiety respectively decreased to and exceeded baseline levels."
  - "This finding indicates that the applied PA counseling strategies were insufficient to maintain enhanced levels of subjective health over a two-year follow-up period."
  - "Consequently, the implementation of booster sessions might be needed in order to maintain improved levels of subjective health."
column31:
- The study had follow-up periods at 10 weeks, 1 year, and 2 years after the intervention.
- At the 10-week follow-up, there were significant improvements in both well-being and trait anxiety.
- At the 1-year follow-up, well-being and trait anxiety continued to show improvements compared to baseline.
- However, by the 2-year follow-up, well-being had returned to baseline levels, indicating a relapse, while trait anxiety had increased significantly compared to baseline.
- The data suggests that the interventions were effective in the short term but not sustainable over a longer period, as both well-being and trait anxiety showed significant changes at the 2-year follow-up that were not in the direction of improvement.
- The study highlights the need for booster sessions to maintain improved levels of subjective health.

column10:

column13:

column14:

column16:

column17:

column20:

column23:

column26:

All items were answered originally on an eleven-points scale from 0 (not at all) to 10 (completely) and were subsequently recoded from 1 to 11."

  - "This was performed using motivational interviewing (23,36,37) and health coaching (26)."

column25:

  - "Perceptions of health were measured using the EuroQol EQ-5D-5L (42), which has five domains focusing on mobility, selfcare, usual activities, pain/discomfort, and anxiety/depression,"
  - "Mental wellbeing scores were approximately normally distributed (see Table 2 ) but data loss at each follow-up time point was substantial (data loss at: 3 months = 41%, 6 months = 45%, 12 months = 64%)."

column29:

  - "At the end of the 12-month programme, users showed sustained improvements in physical activity (by +1331 METS), exceeding weekly recommendations."
  - "Sitting (reducing by over an hour per day), sporting participation, and perceptions of health were also improved, with improvements in mental wellbeing in the first 3 months."
  - "At each follow-up time point a substantial data loss occurred due to missed appointments or evaluation dropouts (data loss at: 3 months = 41%, 6 months = 44%, 12 months = 64%)."

  - "The reduction in daily sitting was maintained until the end of the programme as the mean at 12 months was still significantly lower (66 min) compared with the baseline."
  - "The planned comparisons (Table 3 ) suggest a significant yet modest improvement in the average perceived health at 3 months (d = 0.35) as well as for the whole follow-up period (d =0.33), but no further gains for the periods from 3 to 6 or from 6 to 12 months."

column31:

- The study notes substantial data loss at follow-up points, which could affect the reliability of long-term outcomes.
- The evidence suggests sustained effects in physical activity and sitting time, but less so in mental wellbeing.

- "We used data collected at 3-year intervals (1998 to 2019) from 11,336 participants in the Australian Longitudinal Study on Women’s Health (ALSWH) (1946 to 1951 birth cohort)."
  - "Primary outcomes were the physical (PCS) and mental health component summary (MCS) scores (range from 0 to 100; higher scores indicate higher perceived physical/mental health) from the SF-36 in 2019 (when women aged 68 to 73 years)."
  - "Using target trial emulation to imitate a randomized controlled trial (RCT), we tested 2 interventions: (1) meeting the World Health Organization (WHO) physical activity guidelines consistently throughout the 15-year “exposure period” (2001 to 2016; when women aged 50–55 to 65–70 years; physical activity assessed every 3 years); and (2) not meeting the guidelines at the beginning of the exposure period but starting to first meet the guidelines at age 55, 60, or 65; against the control of not meeting the guidelines throughout the exposure period."
  - "Consistent adherence to guidelines during the exposure period (PCS: 46.93 [99.5% confidence interval [CI]: 46.32, 47.54]) and first starting to meet the guidelines at age 55 (PCS: 46.96 [99.5% CI: 45.53, 48.40]) were associated with three-point higher PCS (mean score difference: 3.0 [99.5% CI: 1.8, 4.1] and 3.0 [99.5% CI:1.2, 4.8]) than consistent non-adherence (PCS: 43.90 [99.5% CI: 42.79, 45.01])."

  - "While starting to meet guidelines upon reaching 55 years was associated with a similarly higher PCS (46.96 [45.53, 48.40] ; mean difference versus control: 3.0 [99.5% CI: 1.2, 4.8]), starting to meet guidelines upon reaching 60 (mean difference versus control: 1.1 [99.5% CI: -0.6, 2.8]) and 65 (mean difference versus control: 0.2 [99.5% CI: -0.9, 1.3]) were not associated with statistically different PCS compared with the control."
  - "In terms of subscales (Tables B and J and Fig A in S6 Text), analyses show 5-to 9-point differences between consistent adherence to guidelines and consistent non-adherence in all 4 physical subscales, with the largest effect observed for "physical functioning" (mean difference: 9.3 [99.5% CI: 6.2, 12.3])."
  - "We found no statistically significant differences in MCS between any hypothetical intervention and the control."

Starting the exposure period meeting the guidelines, but then stopping meeting them on reaching age 65 was associated with nearly a three-point higher PCS than consistent non-adherence."

  - "There were no statistically significant differences in MCS between any hypothetical intervention and the control."
  - "In sensitivity analyses using a lower threshold of 75 min per week of physical activity, patterns for the primary (Table C and Figs D and E in S6 Text) and secondary analyses (Table D and Figs F and G in S6 Text) were similar, but differences were less marked."
